foods.name: Avocado
foods.fun_fact: High in healthy fats essential for brain development. Your baby's brain is about 60% fat!

video_links.title: How to Serve Avocado to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cut into quarters lengthwise, remove pit and skin
phase_1.serving_tip: Roll in hemp seeds, crushed cheerios, or infant cereal for grip—otherwise too slippery

phase_2.preparation: Dice into chickpea-sized pieces or slice thin
phase_2.serving_tip: Great mashed on toast strips too

foods.name: Banana
foods.fun_fact: High in potassium and B6, essential for nerve function and brain development.

video_links.title: How to Serve Banana to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cut in half crosswise, leave bottom half of peel on as a 'handle'
phase_1.serving_tip: The peel gives grip and prevents baby from stuffing whole piece in mouth
phase_1.safety_note: Very ripe banana can be gummy—watch for gagging

phase_2.preparation: Slice into rounds, then halve if large
phase_2.serving_tip: Roll in hemp seeds if too slippery

foods.name: Mango
foods.fun_fact: The mango pit is a perfect resistive teether—baby can gnaw safely while getting nutrients!

video_links.title: How to Serve Mango to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cut cheeks off pit, slice into long strips. Or offer the pit itself to gnaw on.
phase_1.serving_tip: Leave skin on the end as a handle, or score flesh in grid pattern while still on skin

phase_2.preparation: Dice into small pieces
phase_2.serving_tip: Pairs well with yogurt

foods.name: Strawberry
foods.fun_fact: Vitamin C from strawberries helps your baby absorb iron 2-3x better when eaten together!

video_links.title: How to Serve Strawberries to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Remove stem. Serve whole if very large (golf ball+), halve if medium
phase_1.serving_tip: Great Vitamin C source—pair with iron-rich foods to boost absorption
phase_1.safety_note: Quarter lengthwise if strawberry is small or firm

phase_2.preparation: Quarter lengthwise, then chop smaller

foods.name: Blueberry
foods.fun_fact: Rich in antioxidants called anthocyanins that support brain development and memory.

video_links.title: How to Serve Blueberries to Babies
Why Whole Blueberries Are Dangerous

phase_1.preparation: Press each berry flat with fork or fingers until skin breaks
phase_1.serving_tip: Can also mash into oatmeal or yogurt
phase_1.safety_note: NEVER serve whole—perfect choking shape. Must be flattened or quartered.

phase_2.preparation: Flatten with fork or cut in half/quarters
phase_2.safety_note: Still flatten or quarter until confident with chewing

foods.name: Peach
foods.fun_fact: Peaches contain natural fiber that supports healthy digestion as baby transitions to solids.

video_links.title: How to Serve Peaches to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cut into wedges, leave skin on (provides grip and fiber)
phase_1.serving_tip: Choose ripe peaches that yield to gentle pressure
phase_1.safety_note: If skin is tough, lightly score it or remove

phase_2.preparation: Remove skin if desired, dice into small pieces

foods.name: Watermelon
foods.fun_fact: Over 90% water, making it great for hydration on hot days when starting solids!

video_links.title: How to Serve Watermelon to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cut into thick sticks about 2 fingers wide. Remove all visible seeds.
phase_1.serving_tip: Leave rind on as a handle—baby gnaws the flesh
phase_1.safety_note: Remove seeds thoroughly—choking hazard

phase_2.preparation: Cut into bite-sized cubes, remove seeds and rind

foods.name: Apple
foods.fun_fact: Contains pectin, a prebiotic fiber that feeds the good bacteria in baby's developing gut!

video_links.title: How to Serve Apples to Babies Safely

phase_1.preparation: Steam or roast until very soft. OR grate raw apple finely.
phase_1.serving_tip: Thin slices of raw apple can work if paper-thin and baby can gum them
phase_1.safety_note: RAW APPLE CHUNKS ARE HIGH CHOKING RISK. Must be cooked soft or grated until 2+ years.

phase_2.shape: Soft cooked pieces or shredded raw
phase_2.preparation: Bake/steam and dice, or continue grating raw
phase_2.serving_tip: Mix grated apple into oatmeal
phase_2.safety_note: Raw apple pieces remain high risk until well-established chewing

foods.name: Broccoli
foods.fun_fact: The stem makes a perfect natural handle for baby's palmar grasp—one of the best first BLW foods!

video_links.title: How to Serve Broccoli to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Steam until fork-tender (about 8-10 min). Leave long stem attached.
phase_1.serving_tip: The stem is a natural handle—baby holds stem, eats floret. One of the best first BLW foods.

phase_2.preparation: Steam and cut into smaller pieces
phase_2.serving_tip: Great tossed in olive oil and parmesan

foods.name: Sweet Potato
foods.fun_fact: One of the richest sources of beta-carotene, which converts to Vitamin A for healthy eyes and immune function!

video_links.title: How to Serve Sweet Potato to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cut into wedges (with skin on for grip), roast at 400°F until soft (~25 min)
phase_1.serving_tip: Leave skin on—provides texture for grip. Toss in olive oil before roasting.

phase_2.preparation: Roast and dice, or mash for preloaded spoon

foods.name: Carrot
foods.fun_fact: Raw carrots are a top choking hazard for babies—always cook until soft or grate finely until age 2+!

video_links.title: How to Serve Carrots Safely to Babies
Steamed Carrot Sticks for BLW

phase_1.preparation: Steam or roast whole carrots until very soft, then cut into sticks. OR grate raw finely.
phase_1.serving_tip: Test softness—should smush easily between fingers
phase_1.safety_note: RAW CARROT is HIGH CHOKING RISK. Must be cooked very soft or finely grated until 2+ years.

phase_2.preparation: Steam/roast and dice
phase_2.serving_tip: Mix grated raw carrot into meatballs or patties

foods.name: Zucchini
foods.fun_fact: Mild flavor makes it perfect for hiding in baked goods—great for picky eater prevention!

video_links.title: How to Serve Zucchini to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cut into thick sticks, steam or sauté until soft
phase_1.serving_tip: Can be slippery—leave skin on for grip

phase_2.preparation: Slice into rounds or dice, cook until soft
phase_2.serving_tip: Great in fritters or mixed into pasta

foods.name: Bell Pepper
foods.fun_fact: Red bell peppers have 3x more Vitamin C than oranges—perfect for boosting iron absorption!

video_links.title: How to Serve Bell Pepper to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cut into wide strips, roast until very soft and skin wrinkles. Peel skin if tough.
phase_1.serving_tip: Red/orange/yellow are sweeter than green. Excellent Vitamin C—pair with iron foods.
phase_1.safety_note: Raw pepper skin can be tough to chew—roast until soft for early eaters

phase_2.preparation: Roast and slice, or dice into small pieces
phase_2.serving_tip: Great raw if sliced very thin for older babies

foods.name: Butternut Squash
foods.fun_fact: Rich in beta-carotene and naturally sweet—babies often love this one from the start!

video_links.title: How to Serve Butternut Squash to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cut into wedges or thick sticks, roast at 400°F until very soft (~30 min)
phase_1.serving_tip: Leave skin on bottom for grip, scoop flesh

phase_2.preparation: Roast and dice, or mash for spoon
phase_2.serving_tip: Great mixed with cinnamon

foods.name: Peas
foods.fun_fact: One of the highest protein vegetables—great for plant-based iron and muscle development!

video_links.title: How to Serve Peas to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cook and lightly smash each pea, or mash into patties with other ingredients
phase_1.serving_tip: Whole peas are hard to pick up with palmar grasp—mix into mashable foods
phase_1.safety_note: Lightly flatten to break skin

phase_2.preparation: Serve whole for pincer grasp practice, smash if concerned
phase_2.serving_tip: Great for pincer grasp practice

foods.name: Spinach
foods.fun_fact: Contains non-heme iron—pair with Vitamin C foods to boost absorption by up to 6x!

video_links.title: How to Serve Spinach to Babies

phase_1.shape: Cooked and finely chopped, or mixed in
phase_1.preparation: Sauté or steam until wilted, chop finely. Mix into eggs, patties, or sauces.
phase_1.serving_tip: Raw leafy greens can stick to throat—always cook for young babies
phase_1.safety_note: Do not serve raw—difficult to chew and can stick to back of throat

phase_2.preparation: Continue cooking and mixing into foods
phase_2.serving_tip: Add to smoothies, scrambled eggs, pasta sauce

foods.name: Beef
foods.fun_fact: Heme iron from beef is absorbed 2-3x better than plant iron. Baby sucks the iron-rich juices—this is perfect!

video_links.title: How to Serve Beef to Babies
Steak Strips for Baby Led Weaning

phase_1.preparation: Slow cook beef (brisket, chuck roast) until fall-apart tender, then cut into thick strips. OR offer a large steak strip cooked medium—baby sucks juices.
phase_1.serving_tip: Baby won't actually eat much meat fiber—they're sucking the iron-rich juices. This is perfect.
phase_1.safety_note: Size matters: too small = choking risk. Keep pieces LARGE so baby gnaws, doesn't swallow whole.

phase_2.preparation: Shred slow-cooked beef, or offer ground beef crumbles/meatballs
phase_2.serving_tip: Ground beef in tomato sauce is iron + vitamin C pairing

foods.name: Chicken (Dark Meat)
foods.fun_fact: Dark meat (thighs, drumsticks) has 2x more iron and more healthy fats than white breast meat!

video_links.title: How to Serve Chicken to Babies
Drumstick for Baby Led Weaning

phase_1.preparation: Slow cook or braise thighs until very tender. Offer drumstick to gnaw (remove loose cartilage/skin) or cut thigh into thick strips.
phase_1.serving_tip: Dark meat (thighs, drums) has more iron and fat than breast. Breast meat can be dry and stringy.
phase_1.safety_note: Check for bone fragments. Keep pieces large.

phase_2.preparation: Shred into small pieces
phase_2.serving_tip: Mix shredded chicken with sauce to add moisture
phase_2.safety_note: Dry chicken can be hard to swallow—add moisture

foods.name: Salmon
foods.fun_fact: Wild salmon contains DHA omega-3s critical for brain and eye development—baby's brain grows fastest in the first year!

video_links.title: How to Serve Salmon to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Bake or poach until fully cooked and flaky. Offer a large piece to grip and gnaw, or form into a patty/log shape.
phase_1.serving_tip: Wild salmon has excellent omega-3s for brain development. Check thoroughly for bones.
phase_1.safety_note: CHECK FOR BONES. Run fingers over flesh before serving. Major allergen—introduce carefully.

phase_2.preparation: Flake into small pieces or make salmon patties
phase_2.serving_tip: Canned salmon (bones removed) works great for patties

foods.name: Sardines
foods.fun_fact: The tiny soft bones are safe to eat and provide calcium for growing bones! One of the most nutrient-dense foods.

video_links.title: How to Serve Sardines to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Use canned sardines in water or olive oil (low sodium). Mash with fork or offer whole small fish to gnaw.
phase_1.serving_tip: Tiny soft bones are safe to eat and add calcium. Incredibly nutrient-dense—iron, omega-3, vitamin D.
phase_1.safety_note: Major allergen—introduce carefully. Choose low-sodium options.

phase_2.preparation: Mash onto toast or flake into pasta
phase_2.serving_tip: Mix with avocado to mellow flavor

foods.name: Egg
foods.fun_fact: The LEAP study showed early egg introduction (before 12 months) reduces allergy risk by up to 80%!

video_links.title: How to Serve Eggs to Babies
Early Allergen Introduction

phase_1.preparation: Make thin omelet, cut into strips. OR hard-boil, quarter lengthwise.
phase_1.serving_tip: Eggs must be fully cooked (no runny yolk) to avoid salmonella risk in babies.
phase_1.safety_note: MAJOR ALLERGEN. Introduce early (reduces allergy risk per LEAP research). Must be fully cooked.

phase_2.preparation: Soft scramble into small curds, or dice hard-boiled
phase_2.serving_tip: Scrambled eggs are great for preloaded spoon or pincer grasp

foods.name: Tofu
foods.fun_fact: Excellent plant-based iron source! Pan-frying creates a grippy exterior that's easier for baby to hold.

video_links.title: How to Serve Tofu to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Use firm or extra-firm tofu. Cut into thick finger-length strips. Can serve raw, pan-fried, or baked.
phase_1.serving_tip: Pan-frying creates a grippy exterior. Excellent plant-based iron source.
phase_1.safety_note: Soy is a major allergen—introduce carefully.

phase_2.preparation: Dice into small cubes, pan-fry for texture
phase_2.serving_tip: Great in stir-fries and curries

foods.name: Lentils
foods.fun_fact: One cup of cooked lentils has more iron than 3oz of beef! Pair with vitamin C for best absorption.

video_links.title: How to Serve Lentils to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cook until very soft, mash partially. Form into patties or spread on toast.
phase_1.serving_tip: Pair with vitamin C (tomatoes, peppers, citrus) to boost iron absorption. Dal is perfect BLW food.

phase_2.preparation: Serve whole cooked lentils or in soups/stews
phase_2.serving_tip: Red lentils cook down to mush—great for sauces. Green/brown hold shape better.

foods.name: Chickpeas
foods.fun_fact: Hummus (made from chickpeas and tahini) covers two allergens at once—sesame and chickpeas!

video_links.title: How to Serve Chickpeas to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cook until very soft (canned works), smash each one lightly to break skin. Or serve as hummus on toast strips.
phase_1.serving_tip: Hummus is an excellent early BLW food—spread thin on toast or offer for dipping.
phase_1.safety_note: Flatten slightly to break skin—reduces choking risk

phase_2.preparation: Smash lightly or roast until slightly crispy outside, soft inside
phase_2.serving_tip: Great pincer grasp food

foods.name: Black Beans
foods.fun_fact: Packed with fiber and protein—great for building healthy gut bacteria during the critical early months!

video_links.title: How to Serve Black Beans to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cook until soft (canned works—rinse well), mash or smash individually
phase_1.serving_tip: Pair with mango or citrus for vitamin C boost. Great in quesadillas.

phase_2.preparation: Serve whole for pincer grasp
phase_2.serving_tip: Mix into rice, tacos, or serve plain

foods.name: Yogurt (Full-Fat Plain)
foods.fun_fact: Babies need full-fat dairy for brain development—avoid low-fat until age 2. Yogurt is safe before milk as a drink!

video_links.title: How to Serve Yogurt to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Load yogurt onto spoon, hand spoon to baby
phase_1.serving_tip: Full-fat plain yogurt is best—babies need fat for brain development. Avoid added sugars.
phase_1.safety_note: Dairy is a major allergen—introduce carefully. Yogurt is safe before cow's milk as a drink.

phase_2.preparation: Same—offer loaded spoon or as dip for fruits
phase_2.serving_tip: Greek yogurt is thicker and easier to manage

foods.name: Cheese
foods.fun_fact: Cheese cubes are actually a choking hazard because they're rubbery! Always serve thin strips or melted.

video_links.title: How to Serve Cheese Safely to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cut into very thin strips (not cubes), or grate/shred. Soft cheeses can be spread.
phase_1.serving_tip: Avoid cubes—rubbery texture is choking risk. Thin strips or melted on toast works better.
phase_1.safety_note: NO CUBES. Cheese cubes are rubbery and hard to chew. Cut into thin strips or shred.

phase_2.preparation: Thin slices, shredded, or melted into dishes
phase_2.serving_tip: Ricotta and cottage cheese work well on spoons

foods.name: Peanut Butter
foods.fun_fact: The LEAP study proved early peanut intro (4-11mo) reduces allergy risk by 81%! Introduce early and often.

video_links.title: How to Serve Peanut Butter Safely
LEAP Study and Early Allergen Introduction

phase_1.preparation: Thin with water, breastmilk, or formula until sauce consistency. Mix into oatmeal/yogurt. OR spread paper-thin on toast.
phase_1.serving_tip: Early peanut introduction (4-11mo) reduces allergy risk by up to 81% (LEAP study). Introduce EARLY.
phase_1.safety_note: NEVER OFFER A GLOB OR THICK SPREAD. Thick peanut butter is a serious choking/aspiration hazard. Must be thinned or spread translucent-thin.

phase_2.preparation: Continue thinning or spreading very thin
phase_2.serving_tip: Bamba puffs (Israeli peanut snack) are great—dissolve in mouth

foods.name: Almond Butter
foods.fun_fact: Tree nut allergies are separate from peanut allergies—introduce each type of nut separately.

video_links.title: How to Serve Tree Nut Butters to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Same as peanut butter—thin with liquid or spread paper-thin on toast
phase_1.serving_tip: Tree nut allergen—introduce after peanut if doing one allergen at a time
phase_1.safety_note: Same as peanut butter—NEVER thick globs. High aspiration risk.

phase_2.preparation: Continue thinning or spreading very thin

foods.name: Tahini
foods.fun_fact: Sesame became the 9th major allergen in 2023. Tahini-based hummus covers two allergens at once!

video_links.title: How to Serve Tahini to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Stir well (separates), thin if very thick. Mix into oatmeal, yogurt, or hummus. Spread thin on toast.
phase_1.serving_tip: Sesame is now a top-9 allergen. Excellent iron source. Tahini-based hummus covers two allergens.
phase_1.safety_note: Sesame allergen—introduce carefully.

phase_2.preparation: Use in sauces, dressings, hummus
phase_2.serving_tip: Great drizzled on roasted vegetables

foods.name: Shrimp
foods.fun_fact: Shellfish allergy is separate from fish allergy—being allergic to one doesn't mean you're allergic to the other.

video_links.title: How to Serve Shrimp to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Fully cook. Serve whole large shrimp to gnaw, or mince/chop finely and mix into other foods.
phase_1.serving_tip: If baby can grip a whole shrimp, they can gnaw on it. Otherwise mince.
phase_1.safety_note: Major allergen—introduce carefully. Must be fully cooked.

phase_2.preparation: Chop into small pieces or serve whole if manageable
phase_2.serving_tip: Great in pasta or rice dishes

foods.name: Toast/Bread
foods.fun_fact: Toasting changes the texture so bread dissolves better than soft bread, which can gum up in baby's mouth.

video_links.title: How to Serve Toast to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Toast bread lightly (not too crispy), cut into 2-finger-wide strips
phase_1.serving_tip: Toasting changes texture—makes it dissolve better than soft bread which can gum up. Great vehicle for spreads (hummus, nut butters, avocado).
phase_1.safety_note: Soft white bread can be gummy and stick in mouth. Toast lightly. Sourdough or whole grain works well.

phase_2.preparation: Continue with strips or cut into smaller pieces
phase_2.serving_tip: Can increase toasting as chewing improves

foods.name: Pasta
foods.fun_fact: Tube shapes like penne and rigatoni are easiest for baby's palmar grasp—they can thread it on their fingers!

video_links.title: How to Serve Pasta to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cook until soft. Fusilli, rigatoni, or penne work well—easy to grip. Or offer long spaghetti strands.
phase_1.serving_tip: Tube shapes are easiest to grip with palmar grasp. Spaghetti is messy but fun.

phase_2.preparation: Cut long pasta if concerned, otherwise serve as-is
phase_2.serving_tip: Add sauce for nutrition and fun

foods.name: Oatmeal
foods.fun_fact: Baby oatmeal is often iron-fortified—check the label! Great base for mixing in nut butters and fruits.

video_links.title: Oatmeal Balls for Baby Led Weaning
How to Serve Oatmeal to Babies

phase_1.shape: Preloaded spoon or thick enough to form balls
phase_1.preparation: Cook oats thick (less liquid). Load onto spoon for baby to grab, or form into balls/fingers if thick enough.
phase_1.serving_tip: Often fortified with iron—check label. Great base for mixing in nut butters, fruit, seeds.

phase_2.shape: Preloaded spoon or baked into fingers
phase_2.preparation: Spoon-feed or bake into oat bars/fingers
phase_2.serving_tip: Overnight oats, baked oatmeal bars, or oat pancakes all work

foods.name: Rice
foods.fun_fact: Rice absorbs more arsenic than other grains—rinse well, cook in excess water, and vary grains for safety.

video_links.title: How to Serve Rice to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cook sticky/sushi rice, form into balls or logs. Or mix into lentil/bean patties.
phase_1.serving_tip: Loose rice is hard to pick up—form into shapes or mix with sticky foods.
phase_1.safety_note: Rice absorbs arsenic more than other grains. Rinse well, cook in excess water, drain. Vary grains—don't rely solely on rice.

phase_2.preparation: Can serve loose for pincer grasp practice, or in mixed dishes

foods.name: Quinoa
foods.fun_fact: One of the few plant foods that's a complete protein—contains all 9 essential amino acids!

video_links.title: How to Serve Quinoa to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cook and mix into patties, meatballs, or mashed foods
phase_1.serving_tip: Complete protein (all amino acids). Great iron source. Too small to pick up alone at first.
phase_1.safety_note: Rinse well before cooking to remove bitter coating

phase_2.preparation: Serve loose for pincer grasp or in mixed dishes

foods.name: Pancakes
foods.fun_fact: Easy to fortify with hidden nutrition—blend in spinach, banana, pumpkin, or nut butter!

video_links.title: Baby Pancake Recipes

phase_1.preparation: Make thin pancakes, cut into finger-width strips
phase_1.serving_tip: Easy to fortify—add mashed banana, pumpkin, spinach, nut butter to batter. Can be egg-free (allergen management).
phase_1.safety_note: If using egg in batter, counts toward egg allergen exposure

phase_2.preparation: Cut into strips or bite-sized pieces
phase_2.serving_tip: Freeze extras for quick meals

foods.name: Edamame
foods.fun_fact: Never serve in pods—they're a choking hazard. Always remove beans and smash to break the skin.

video_links.title: How to Serve Edamame to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cook, remove from pods, smash each bean or mash into a spread
phase_1.serving_tip: Never serve in pods—choking hazard. Smash to break skin.
phase_1.safety_note: Soy allergen. Do not serve in pods. Smash or flatten each bean.

phase_2.preparation: Smash lightly or serve whole for pincer grasp

foods.name: Liver (Chicken/Beef)
foods.fun_fact: The most iron-dense food available! Grate frozen liver into pasta sauce—baby won't even taste it.

video_links.title: How to Serve Liver to Babies
Hidden Liver Recipes for Babies

phase_1.preparation: Make into pâté and spread on toast strips. Or cook and cut into strips.
phase_1.serving_tip: MOST iron-dense food. A little goes a long way. Limit to 1-2x per week due to high Vitamin A.
phase_1.safety_note: Limit frequency due to high Vitamin A content which can be toxic in excess.

phase_2.preparation: Spread on toast or chop into dishes
phase_2.serving_tip: Chicken liver pâté is milder in flavor

foods.name: Lamb
foods.fun_fact: Like beef, lamb provides highly absorbable heme iron. Baby sucks the nutritious juices while gnawing!

video_links.title: How to Serve Lamb to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Slow cook until tender, cut into thick strips. Or offer lamb chop bone to gnaw.
phase_1.serving_tip: Similar to beef—baby sucks iron-rich juices. Excellent iron source.
phase_1.safety_note: Keep pieces large. Check for bone fragments if offering chop.

phase_2.preparation: Shred or use ground lamb in patties, meatballs
phase_2.serving_tip: Great in Mediterranean-spiced dishes

foods.name: Hummus
foods.fun_fact: Covers two allergens at once—sesame (from tahini) and chickpeas! A BLW staple food.

video_links.title: How to Serve Hummus to Babies

phase_1.shape: Spread on toast or for dipping
phase_1.preparation: Spread on toast strips, or offer as dip with vegetable spears
phase_1.serving_tip: Covers sesame allergen (tahini) and chickpeas. High iron. Excellent BLW food.
phase_1.safety_note: Contains sesame (tahini)—introduce as allergen. Check label for other allergens.

phase_2.preparation: Same—spread or dip
phase_2.serving_tip: Make your own to control salt content

foods.name: Meatballs (Beef/Turkey/Chicken)
foods.fun_fact: Shape matters! Oval/log shapes are safer than round balls because they won't plug the airway.

video_links.title: Safe Meatball Shapes for Babies

phase_1.preparation: Form ground meat into oval/log shapes (not perfect spheres). Bake until cooked through.
phase_1.serving_tip: Oval shape is safer than round—less likely to plug airway. Add grated veggies to boost nutrition.
phase_1.safety_note: Avoid perfect round balls—shape into ovals or flatten slightly to reduce choking risk.

phase_2.preparation: Quarter meatballs or crumble into smaller pieces
phase_2.serving_tip: Great in pasta sauce (iron + vitamin C pairing)

foods.name: Cod
foods.fun_fact: Mild white fish is often the best first fish for babies—less fishy taste than salmon or sardines.

video_links.title: How to Serve Cod to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Bake or poach until flaky. Offer large piece to grip.
phase_1.serving_tip: Mild white fish—good intro to fish allergen. Check thoroughly for bones.
phase_1.safety_note: Fish allergen—introduce carefully. Check meticulously for bones.

phase_2.preparation: Flake into pieces or form into cakes
phase_2.serving_tip: Great in fish tacos or fish cakes

foods.name: Greek Yogurt (Full-Fat Plain)
foods.fun_fact: Thicker than regular yogurt with 2x the protein—easier for babies to manage on a spoon!

video_links.title: How to Serve Greek Yogurt to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Load onto spoon, hand to baby
phase_1.serving_tip: Thicker than regular yogurt—easier to manage. Higher protein. Avoid sweetened varieties.
phase_1.safety_note: Dairy allergen—introduce carefully.

phase_2.preparation: Same as phase 1
phase_2.serving_tip: Great base for mixing in fruit, nut butters, seeds

foods.name: Ricotta Cheese
foods.fun_fact: Soft, mild, and spreadable—one of the easiest cheeses for babies to enjoy safely.

video_links.title: How to Serve Ricotta to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Spread on toast strips or load onto spoon
phase_1.serving_tip: Soft texture, mild flavor. Great mixed with mashed fruit.
phase_1.safety_note: Dairy allergen.

phase_2.preparation: Same—spread or mix into dishes
phase_2.serving_tip: Great in pasta dishes

foods.name: Kiwi
foods.fun_fact: One of the highest Vitamin C fruits—even higher than oranges! The seeds are safe to eat.

video_links.title: How to Serve Kiwi to Babies

phase_1.shape: Halved with skin, or thick slices
phase_1.preparation: Cut in half, leave skin on—baby scoops flesh with mouth. Or peel and slice into thick wedges.
phase_1.serving_tip: Very high in vitamin C—great iron pairing. Seeds are fine to eat.
phase_1.safety_note: Can cause mouth tingling in some babies (actinidin enzyme)—not an allergy, but watch for reaction

phase_2.preparation: Peel and slice or dice

foods.name: Orange
foods.fun_fact: The membrane around each segment is tough to chew—remove it (called supreming) for safe serving!

video_links.title: How to Serve Oranges to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Peel, separate into segments, remove the membrane/skin around each segment (supreming)
phase_1.serving_tip: Membrane is tough to chew—remove it. The flesh itself is soft. Great vitamin C source.
phase_1.safety_note: Remove membrane—choking risk. Seeds must be removed.

phase_2.preparation: Remove membrane, cut into pieces if needed

foods.name: Tomato
foods.fun_fact: Cherry and grape tomatoes are perfect choking shape when whole—always quarter lengthwise!

video_links.title: How to Cut Tomatoes Safely for Babies

phase_1.shape: Large wedges or quartered cherry tomatoes
phase_1.preparation: Large tomato: cut into wedges. Cherry/grape tomatoes: quarter lengthwise (NEVER whole).
phase_1.serving_tip: Great vitamin C for iron absorption. Skin provides grip.
phase_1.safety_note: NEVER serve cherry/grape tomatoes whole—perfect choking shape. Must quarter lengthwise.

phase_2.preparation: Quarter small tomatoes, dice large ones
phase_2.serving_tip: Great in sauces, which pair well with iron-rich proteins

foods.name: Asparagus
foods.fun_fact: Natural handle shape makes it a perfect first finger food—baby holds the stem and eats the tip!

video_links.title: How to Serve Asparagus to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Snap off woody ends, steam or roast until soft
phase_1.serving_tip: Natural handle shape—perfect for BLW. Baby holds stem, eats tip.

phase_2.preparation: Whole spears or cut into pieces
phase_2.serving_tip: Great roasted with olive oil and parmesan

foods.name: Cauliflower
foods.fun_fact: Like broccoli, the stem is a natural handle! Contains Vitamin C to boost iron absorption.

video_links.title: How to Serve Cauliflower to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Steam or roast until fork-tender. Keep stem attached as handle.
phase_1.serving_tip: Like broccoli—stem is the handle. Good vitamin C source.

phase_2.preparation: Smaller florets or mash for spoon
phase_2.serving_tip: Great mashed with butter and cheese

foods.name: Green Beans
foods.fun_fact: Natural finger shape makes them a perfect early BLW food—easy to grip and gum!

video_links.title: How to Serve Green Beans to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Steam until soft, serve whole (trim ends)
phase_1.serving_tip: Natural finger shape. Easy to grip.

phase_2.preparation: Whole or cut into pieces

foods.name: Cucumber
foods.fun_fact: Cooling and hydrating—great for teething discomfort! Score the skin with a fork to add grip.

video_links.title: How to Serve Cucumber to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cut into thick spears. Score skin with fork for grip. Can also peel if preferred.
phase_1.serving_tip: Cooling and hydrating. Good for teething. Low calorie—not a main food.
phase_1.safety_note: Skin can be slippery—score with fork or partially peel

phase_2.preparation: Spears or thick rounds

foods.name: Corn
foods.fun_fact: Corn kernels pass through undigested—totally normal! Cob gnawing is great for oral development.

video_links.title: How to Serve Corn to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Cook corn on cob, cut into small sections for baby to gnaw. Or cut kernels off and mash/mix into other foods.
phase_1.serving_tip: Whole kernels pass through undigested—normal! Cob gnawing is good for oral development.
phase_1.safety_note: Individual kernels can be hard to chew—mash or flatten for young babies

phase_2.preparation: Serve kernels or cob sections

foods.name: Beets
foods.fun_fact: Will stain everything red—consider it a rite of passage! Great source of natural nitrates for blood flow.

video_links.title: How to Serve Beets to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Roast whole until soft, peel, cut into wedges or sticks
phase_1.serving_tip: Will stain everything red—be prepared! Good iron source.

phase_2.preparation: Dice or grate into dishes
phase_2.serving_tip: Great in pancakes or muffins (hides well)

foods.name: Pork
foods.fun_fact: Choose fattier cuts like shoulder for baby—tenderloin can be too dry. Baby sucks the nutritious juices!

video_links.title: How to Serve Pork to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Slow cook pork shoulder until shreddable, cut into strips. Or offer a large rib bone to gnaw.
phase_1.serving_tip: Similar to beef—baby sucks juices and gnaws. Tenderloin can be dry—choose fattier cuts.
phase_1.safety_note: Must be fully cooked. Keep pieces large.

phase_2.preparation: Shred pulled pork or use ground
phase_2.serving_tip: Great in tacos, stir-fries

foods.name: Hemp Seeds (Hemp Hearts)
foods.fun_fact: Excellent iron, protein, and omega-3s! Roll slippery foods like avocado in hemp seeds for better grip.

video_links.title: How to Serve Hemp Seeds to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Sprinkle on yogurt, oatmeal, avocado, etc.
phase_1.serving_tip: Excellent iron, protein, omega-3s. Great for rolling slippery foods (avocado) to add grip.

phase_2.preparation: Same—sprinkle on foods

foods.name: Chia Seeds
foods.fun_fact: Must always be soaked—dry chia can expand and clump in baby's throat! Chia pudding is a great option.

video_links.title: How to Serve Chia Seeds to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Soak in liquid to form gel (chia pudding), or sprinkle into oatmeal/yogurt
phase_1.serving_tip: Must hydrate—dry chia can clump. Good iron and omega-3 source.
phase_1.safety_note: Always serve hydrated/soaked—dry chia can expand and clump in throat

phase_2.preparation: Same—always hydrated
phase_2.serving_tip: Great in smoothies, puddings

foods.name: Plantain
foods.fun_fact: A staple in Caribbean, Latin American, and African cuisines—ripe (yellow/black) is sweeter and softer!

video_links.title: How to Serve Plantain to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Use ripe (yellow/black) plantain. Bake or steam until soft, cut into strips.
phase_1.serving_tip: Ripe plantain is sweeter and softer. Green plantain is starchier—cook longer.

phase_2.preparation: Slice into rounds or mash (like mofongo/fufu style)
phase_2.serving_tip: Staple in Caribbean, Latin American, African cuisines

foods.name: Turkey (Dark Meat)
foods.fun_fact: Dark meat (legs, thighs) is more moist and nutritious than breast. Ground turkey makes great meatballs!

video_links.title: How to Serve Turkey to Babies

phase_1.preparation: Slow cook dark meat until very tender, cut into strips. Or offer drumstick to gnaw.
phase_1.serving_tip: Dark meat is more moist than breast. Ground turkey works well in meatballs.
phase_1.safety_note: Turkey breast can be very dry—add moisture or choose dark meat

phase_2.preparation: Shred or use ground in patties/meatballs
